BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 31, 1916.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

SENIORS DEFEAT JUNIOR TEAM

ENTRANCE RULES CHANGED

PHYSICS LABORATORY A STUDIO

TRACK TEAM OFF WITH A RUSH

Negative Wins Debate After Hotly Combated Contest—Tingley and Steinbach
Win Laurels The Adams Medal
Awarded to Rothschild.

Spanish,French and German Can Replace
Greek—Entrance Exams in September
Only—Drawing Not Required.

Photographs for 1916 Hullabaloo to Be
Made by New York Man in Third
Floor of Physics Laboratory.

Well-Balanced Squad Shows Promise iu
Every Event—B.A.A.Downed by 58
to 28—Mile Record Equaled.

Several important changes have
recently been made in regard to
admission to the undergraduate
courses at Hopkins. Among these
are the limiting of the entrance examinations to September; the possibility of substituting three years
of Greek, French, German or Spanish, or two years in each of two of
these languages, for the three years
of Greek or the two years of French
and German formerly required; and
the abolition of drawing as an entrance requirement.
These changes all tend to make
entrance into the undergraduate
courses easier. Many a student has
either relinquished the idea of ent-ance altogether or come in laden
with conditions, as a result of failure to take the *necessary three
years' work in Greek or the corresponding two in French and German. Such failure has often been
the result of ignorance of the requirements or of insurmountable
obstacles in the student's preparatory school curriculum. Again,
many students have been forced to
take up languages in these schools
in which they had no interest and
which were not as well adapted to
their future vocations as would have
been work in other languages.
The recognition of Spanish also
will aid those who wish to take up
this language in preparatory school,
but, because of the entrance regulations to be obtained, have been
unable to follow their inclinations.
Entrance examinations have
hitherto been held in both September and June. The setting of the
former month as the official time
of these examinations, however,
does not exclude the taking of the
June examinations. Those who
prefer to take the latter are still
able to do so, only, instead of the
Hopkins examinations, they will
take the examinations of the College Entrance Examination Board.
These examinations will be given in
the Academic Building of the University at Homewood from June 19
to 24, 1916, inclusive. For these
examinations, the Board charges a
fee of five dollars, payable before
June 5, 1916.

Plans for the taking of the Senior
Class pictures for the Hullabaloo
have been announced and the class
banquet committee has been appointed. •
The arrangements for the taking
of the class pictures are the most
novel ever undertaken by any graduating class. The plans were announced at the class meeting last
Tuesday, and all were instructed
to subm:t the time which will be
most convenient for their sittings.
The pictures will be taken on the
top floor of the physics laboratory.
For this purpose the entire upper
floor of the building has been temporarily converted into a studio,
which will be occupied by White,
the New York photographer. Mr.
White has a national reputation for
the theatrical portraits he has made
for the best of the current magazines, and his work is considered
among authorities as among the best
in the country.
The taking of the pictures will
begin this Tuesday. Each member
of the Class of 1916 will be photographed at the time which is most
convenient to him, and six photographs will be taken of each man,
from which he may take his pick.
The price of each picture appearing in the Hullabaloo will be two
dollars and fifty cents, and there
will be a reduction of one dollar to
all seniors who have more than four
dollars' worth of pictures finished.
The senior banquet committee is
as follows: Samuel Leithiser,
chairman; Luke Vickers, Franklin
Ludington, Clarence McDowell and
Edmund Spieker. The banquet is
expected to take place sometime
next month, and the committee expresses itself as confident that, from
point of view of both material and
conviviality, it will be one of the
best ever given by a senior class.
After the appointment of the banquet committee, President Tingley
announced that the senior "party"
would take place at the end of the
year. He also read to the class
extracts from a,letter of the "Hullabaloo" engraver, in which the art
productions which had been sent in
were very highly praised.

Each entrant is to play eleven

The way in which the track team
started its season, by defeating the
athletes of the Baltimore Athletic
Association Saturday night in the
cage by the overwhelming score of
58 to 28, makes the prospects look
particularly bright for the heavy
schedule which has been undertaken
this season, for the performance in
this first meet was certainly one of
an all-around, well-balanced organization. The Black and Blue broke
the tape in every one of the track
contests, with the exception of the
30-yard hurdles, and secured first
place in two of the three field
events, besides winning the relay.
The only cage record equalled
was in the mile run, in which Weeks
nosed out Perkins at the tape, having covered the distance in 4
utes 54Y5 seconds. It is a pleasure
minto see anything done well, and the
coaches and rooters were alike delighted at the masterly way in
which four members of the J. H. U.
distance squad handled this piece of
work. Rosen set the pace for the
first half of the race, and it was
one well calculated to give Hopkins
every advantage of the training her
runners have had, beginning with
the cross-country work in the fall.
For the rest of the distance, Weeks
pressed Perkins hard, making him
run the race of his life, and Bullard
stuck close behind these two. In
the last 20-yard straight-away,
Weeks gave a terrific spurt, snatching victory from Perkins by inches.
Great things are expected from this
clever distance quartet in the dual
meets this spring.
The final event, a 1,600-yard relay, was a thriller. The Baltimore
Athletic Association men had saved
two fresh men and they summoned
all their energy for a final effort.
Another feature that added special
interest to the race was the fact
that Huntley Lloyd, former Hopkins star relay man, was competing
against the Black and Blue. The
Baltimore Athletic Association men
got the jump with the gun, but the
first men on the contesting teams
finished neck and neck. Uhler got
the start and increased the Hopkins
lead to half a lap, but Sutton, who
had already broken the tape in both
of the sprinting events and was
worn out, lost nearly all of this advantage. Fred Hall got a slight
start on Huntley Lloyd and their
four laps around the cage was a
hard fight for every yard. On the
last back-stretch, Lloyd pulled up
almost abreast of his opponent, but
the latter made a spurt around the

At the nineteenth annual interclass debate and public speaking
contest, held last Friday evening
in McCoy Hall, the seniors defeated
the juniors in a hotly contested
struggle, and the Adams medal was
won by Morton K. Rothschild.
The public speaking contest,
which occupied the first place on
the program, was one of the most
interesting which has been heard in
McCoy Hall in recent years. The
three speakers were all of high calibre, and the selections which they
gave were such as to hold the audiench from the first word to the last.
Robert R. Duncan, the first speaker, gave Senator Thurston's speech
on "Intervention in Cuba." He
spoke in a clear, well-modulated
voice, and the interpretation which
he gave to Thurston's stirring appeal was excellent. Reuben Oppenheimer, the next speaker, gave Senator Hoar's speech on "America and
the Philippines." He also interpreted his speech well, using his
voice to the best advantage. Morton K. Rothschild, the last speaker,
gave President Wilson's speech on
"The Significance of the Civil War."
His voice was extremely good, and
his graceful, clean-cut gestures
served to bring out his quiet eloquence to its full advantage.
The subject of the debate was
"Resolved, that for State legislatures a unicameral is preferable to
a bicameral system." The juniors
upheld the affirmative of this ques*tion, the seniors the negative.
The junior team was composed
of Alexander A. Weech, Randolph
Smith and Alexander A. Steinbach,
chairman; Lawrence H. Baker was
alternate and Frederick P. Hall, adviser. The senior team consisted
of Harrison C. Coffin, George F.
Ludington and Thomas J. Tingley,
chairman; with Manuel G. Gichner,
alternate, and Clarence W. McDowell, adviser.
Weech, opening the debate, attacked the bicameral system of legislature and outlined the plan which
the affirmative was proposing. He
spoke quietly and deliberately and
seemed thoroughly at home upon
the platform. Coffin, the first speaker for the negative, plunged into his
subject almost immediately, hurling
shaft after shaft of stinging sarcasm at his opponents, and brilliantly defending the system which they
had attacked. Smith, the second
speaker for the affirmative, continued along the lines which Weech
had outlined. His arguments were

SWIMMERS PROMISING WELL
Many Out for Positions on Independent
Swimming Team—Most of Stars Back.
New Men Showing Up Well.

The independent swimming team
of the University is rapidly rounding into shape, and prospects for
the 1916 season look very prosperous indeed. With the exception of
George Penniman, the team consists
of the same members as last year's
squad, with the addition of McCormick, Kirk, Marshall, Black and
Kefover of the Freshman Class.
H. A. Rowland, last year's captain, who, it was feared at first,
would not be able to swim this year
on account of parental objections,
is back again. Rowland is an especially valuable man to have on the
team, for besides his specialties (the
50 and mo yards), in which he has
won many South Atlantic medals,
he can swim the 220 and the breast
stroke events.
With Captain Hoffman, Woodward and Rowland as a nucleus
around which to build,, the outlook
of the team is very bright indeed.
Fulton, also of last year's team,
has been absent from practice on account of sickness, but is expected to
return this week.
The schedule for this year comprises two trips, besides many encounters at home. Swarthmore,
which was beaten by our team so
badly last year, will again be visited.
The University of Pennsylvania will
be met this year instead of Princeton.
The practices are held three afternoons a week in the Young Men's
Christian Association tank.
Kefover, a freshman from St.
James' School, is showing up well
as a plunger and should give Nicholson a good rub for the position.
Besides Hoffman, the diving department also has Evans, Kirk and
Thurman. The short distances are
to be taken care of by Rowland,
Fulton, Woodward, Nicholson and
arshall, and the longer races will
be pres:ded over by Black, McCormick, Rowland and Primrose. Several other members of the squad are
giving some of these men a hard
task in holding down their positions, and keen competition is shown
among the candidates.
The polo team will presumably be
better this year than last, by reason
of the enlargement of the squad.
Brinton and Johnson, the shining
lights of last year's polo team, are
again back at practice, and with
Hoffman, the two Woodwards, Gorman and Primrose on the squad,
Hopkins should make a name for
herself at water polo.

Mention was made in last week's
NEWS LETTER of the State Missionary Conference of Maryland
College, which will be held this
week at Western Maryland College, Westminster, from February
4 to 6, inclusive. Up to the present
time of writing, fifteen Hopkins'
men have enrolled as delegates.
This is a creditable showing, but
the Young Men's Christian Association officials hope to see the number increased.
The Conference this year will be
a most interesting one. Special
stress will be laid upon the Chinese
Foreign Mission question, but mission work in general will be discussed. Those wishing to become
Hopkins' delegates will kindly report to A. E. Lindley, or R. E. F.
Aler, '16.

Do You Agree With the Juniors?

THE NEWS-LETTER wishes to of-

I•

fer the Class of 1917 its hearty congratulations on the step which it
has taken in regard to military
training at Hopkins. It does so,
not because a course of military
training was favored, but because
the Class of 1917 possessed enough
initiative to put itself on record in
regard to one of the most weighty
questions which is agitating not only
this University, but every college
and university in the United States.
The question of national defense
has swept over this country like a
whirlwind. Twelve months ago,
Hopkins would have regarded a
proposal to institute a course of
military training within its conservative walls only as a question
for a somewhat far-fetched collegiate debate. Now that proposal has
been endorsed by one-fourth of the
undergraduate student body.
This question concerns the students, and, before any decision is
reached which would commit the
Hopkins of the future to a set
course of action, student opinion
should go on record as to what that
decision should be. The Junior
Class has made the first step; the
three other classes should follow,
and follow immediately.

Wanted—Participants.

The interclass debate of last Friday evening gave to the attendant
public, and, incidentally, to a fair
proportion of Hopkins' students, an
insight into a phase of Hopkins'
activities which only comes into the
public sight at rather long intervals,
and which consequently does not
'attract the constant attention which
is accorded to athletic activities.
That this activity, when, for a brief
time, it does hold the stage, is amply capable of occupying it in an interesting manner, was proved by the
large crowd which witnessed the
contest last Friday, and that it represents Hopkins to good advantage
was shown by the speeches of the
debaters themselves.
Within two or three weeks, tryouts will be held for places on the
'Varsity teams which are sent out
to meet the teams of North Carolina and Virginia. For three successive years, Hopkins has been
the winner of this triangular debate, and its success has attracted
attention in the debating circles of
colleges throughout the country.
In the past, the idea seems to
have prevailed that these teams were
chosen almost entirely from the
men who took part in the seniorjunior debates: While the majority
of 'Varsity debaters undoubtedly
have been chosen from this material, the idea in itself is erroneous.
Participation in the try-outs is open

LACROSSE SQUAD SHOWS UP WELL
More Freshmen Should Come Out at
Once, Says Coach Wolfe—Progress
of the Team Excellent.

The recent work of the lacrosse
squad has been very encouraging.
Head Coach Wolfe was delighted
with the spirit and enthusiasm displayed in a practice game held
following the freshman-sophomore
track meet. The team is not as
far advanced as it should be at this
time of the year, but if the men
keep up their excellent work this
handicap will soon be overcome.
Coach Wolfe gave a "chalk" talk
last Saturday.
At present, the coach expects to
begin outdoor practice at Homewood in less than two months, and
the meantime will be spent in perfecting the men in stick-work. Four
days a week are spent on this feature of the game. Wednesday and
Saturday are devoted to team work
and scrimmages.
Although the last appeal for more
men was answered in some measure, there is a great need for more
freshmen, and if the members of
the freshmen class do not immediately respond to that call the hope
for the future of the team will be
darkened. New men are not only
needed for future championships
but also for the present. Mr. Paul
W. Sutton, the captain of the team,
will gladly see any man who is interested in lacrosse, and will give
him any desired information.
Since Carlisle has dropped athletics entirely, the lacrosse team has
been forced to cancel its dates with
that college, and the schedule has
had to be readjusted. Consequently, it is not yet possible to announce
the coming program, but the coaches promise one of the strongest
schedules ever followed.
to every undergraduate; there is no
regulation and no tradition that any
but the best men in those try-outs
shall be chosen.
Again, the fact that for the past
few years the subject of the interclass debate has been the subject
of the triangular contest has discouraged many. This year that
handicap has been removed. The

AMERICAN ACADEMY OFFERS
TWO FELLOWSHIPS IN CLASSICS

The school of classical studies of
the American Academy in Rome announces its annual competitions for
fellowships in classical studies. Two
fellowships—one of $1,000 a year
for one year and one of like amount
to last two years—will be awarded
to the winners of a competition open
to all unmarried citizens of the
United States who comply with a
set of. regulations drawn up by the
academy.
Sections i and 2 of the regulations follow:
"Section 1. All persons desiring
to compete for a fellowship must
fill in a form of application, Which
will be furnished by the secretary
of the academy upon request, and
file the same with the secretary not
later than March 1, together with
such letters of reference and other
documents or evidence as they may
desire to submit. Application and
papers must be submitted in triplicate.

"Sec. 2. They must submit evidence of attainment in Latin literature, Greek literature, Greek and
Roman history and archwology, also
an ability to use German and
French. They will be required to
present published or unpublished
papers, so as to indicate their fitness to undertake special work in
Rome."
The fellows will be selected without examination, other than the submission of the required papers, by
the fellowship jury, of which Dr.
James C. Egbert, Columbia University, is chairman.

STUDENTS INVITED TO CAMPS
General Wood U ges All to Attend the
Camps at Plattsburg and Chattanooga,and Tells of Benefits.

The Maryland League for NaDefense has forwarded the following communication from General
Wood to the president of the senior
class:
HEADQUARTERS EASTERN DEPT.
GOVERNORS ISLAND, NEW
YORK CITY.
January 17, 1916.
Dear Sir—You will find herewith a bulletin containing full information in regard to a military
training camp to be held in your
section of the country with the hope
that you will be interested in this
subject.
You will note, first, that applicants are desired principally from
those who have had college, university,-high school (or corresponding school) education. Non-graduates are not excluded, but each case
will be decided on its merits with a
view to maintaining a level in the
progressive scheme of development.
The training given at these camps is
very intensive, covering in a period
of four weeks as much as possible
of the fundamental education of an
officer. This calls for a well-trained
mind. In the second place, past experience has shown that this class
of young men is the first to join the
colors in time of war, and many of
them regardless of their skill in
military matters receive commissions. This has been the procedure
in times past. It is right and necessary that these young men should be
fully informed,as to the tremendous
responsibility which will come to
them with the command of men and
the irreparable loss which may be
caused by unskilled leadership.
Furthermore, as citizens of military age and as members of the unorganized militia under the constitution, it is necessary for the intelligent discharge of their military obligations that they should be as well
informed as possible on these matters. The President has said in a
recent message * * * "it will
be right enough, right American
policy, based upon our accustomed
principles and practices, to provide
a system by which every citizen who
will volunteer for the training may
be made familiar with ,the use of
modern arms, the rudiments of drill
and maneuver, and the maintenance
and sanitation of camps. We should
encourage such training and make
it a means of discipline which our
young men will learn to value."
* * *
At these camps great stress is laid
upon personal hygiene and camp sanitation and a serious effort is made to
teach men how to take care of themselves in camp and at maneuvers, as
well as to familiarize them with the
use of arms. The conduct of the
camps tends to establish habits of
promptness and exactness, and to
the careful observance and prompt
execution of instructions. A serious

effort is made through lectures to
convey a sound and correct idea of
the military policy of the United
States as exemplified, by our past
wars and particular attention is
given to the general subject of military history.
Secondary to these more serious
purposes of the camp, there is to
be considered the physical benefit
of a healthy, out-of-doors life,
vigorous exercise, discipline, good
food and association With a fine lot
of men from every section of the
country with whom, as past experience shows, a very intimate bond
is formed based on hard work in
camp and maneuvers and the consciousness of serving a good cause.
For these reasons national statesmen and legislators, famous lawyers, great bankers and merchants,
and many high state and city officials have stood elbow to elbow in
the ranks, at such camps, with men
who labor for a daily wage, and
both are prowl of it.
The whole effect of the camps
has been excellent both from the
standpoint of increasing the sense
of each man's responsibility to the
nation for service and his obligation
to fit himself to render it effectively
and efficiently.
Attendance at the camp will not
increase either the legal or moral
obligation of those who attend.
The intention is merely to equip
those taking the course of training
to fulfill with more efficiency and
usefulness obligations which are already laid upon them as citizens of
the United States.
Very sincerely yours,
.LEONARD WOOD,
Major General U. S. Army.
The following is the schedule of
the camps which will be organized
this summer:
Northern Section, (Plattsburg,
N. Y.)—First camp, Senior Division, June 5 to July 22; Second
camp, Junior Division, July 5 to
August 8; Third camp, Senior Division, July 12 to August 8; Fourth
camp, Senior Division, August 10
to September 6.
Southern Section, (Fort Oglethorpe, Ga., Chattanooga)—First
camp, Senior Division, April 3 to
April 3o ; Second camp, Senior Division, May 3 to May 3o; Third
camp, Senior Division, June 3 to
June 3o; Fourth camp, Junior Division, July 5 to August 8.
The Junior Division comprises
undergraduates in colleges, universities, and those students in public
and private schools who have
reached a grade equivalent to senior
class, high school.
The Senior Division comprises
graduates of colleges and universities, and other citizens between the
ages of 21 and 45, who have received an equivalent education.
Further information in regard to
these camps may be obtained by
application to "The Officer in
Charge," Military Training Schools,
Governors Island, N. Y. Indication should be made of the section
preferred.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Sir—I am writing to you in order
to express by appreciation of the
enthusiasm which is being shown
over the class basket-ball contests.
Intra-mural athletic contests are, in
my opinion valuable assets to a college curriculum, and all of the
larger universities are slowly coming back to this idea. I say coming
back because I (being an old-timer)
remember the days when this University played only one football
game a year..with any.outside college. All the other contests were
between the classes.
Not that I do not believe in intercollegiate athletics — in fact, I
advocate it—but this letter purposes to show the appreciation of
the present basket-ball games in the
eyes of an

WOODPECKERS CAN GET DRUNK,
IS VERDICT OF DR. WATSON

Prof. J. 11. Watson, of the Phychology Department of this University, is of the opinion that it is
possible for woodpeckers to get
drunk.
Professor Watson has committed
himself to this statement in answering the inquiry of Prof. Burges
Johnson, and his opinion is quoted
in an article in Harper's Magazine, where the question of the
sobriety of woodpeckers is discussed
by some of the most eminent naturalists in the country.
Professor Johnson became interested in this problem as the result
of certain observations ill a camp
in Maine. The authorities to whom
he wrote concerning this question
disagree widely.
Ernest Thompson Seton says:
"The story of woodpeckers getting
drunk on fermented sap is an absurd fable." John Burroughs answers: "Both. birds and insect's
might get drunk on the fermented
sap." Ernest H. Baynes says: "I
do not think it impossible, perhaps
not improbable."
Professor Watson's answer is:
"I have seen robins in a `loggy' condition upon very ripe berries in the
South."

were three events closed to Hopkins men, in which novices and

Reese came through first in both

Sutton took ten for Hopkins, besides running on the winning relay.

snappy order and is looked upon as

SENIORS DEFEAT JUNIOR TEAM

ENTRANCE RULES CHANGED

PHYSICS LABORATORY A STUDIO

TRACK TEAM OFF WITH A RUSH

Negative Wins Debate After Hotly Combated Contest—Tingley and Steinbach
Win Laurels The Adams Medal
Awarded to Rothschild.

Spanish,French and German Can Replace
Greek—Entrance Exams in September
Only—Drawing Not Required.

Photographs for 1916 Hullabaloo to Be
Made by New York Man in Third
Floor of Physics Laboratory.

Well-Balanced Squad Shows Promise iu
Every Event—B.A.A.Downed by 58
to 28—Mile Record Equaled.

Several important changes have
recently been made in regard to
admission to the undergraduate
courses at Hopkins. Among these
are the limiting of the entrance examinations to September; the possibility of substituting three years
of Greek, French, German or Spanish, or two years in each of two of
these languages, for the three years
of Greek or the two years of French
and German formerly required; and
the abolition of drawing as an entrance requirement.
These changes all tend to make
entrance into the undergraduate
courses easier. Many a student has
either relinquished the idea of ent-ance altogether or come in laden
with conditions, as a result of failure to take the *necessary three
years' work in Greek or the corresponding two in French and German. Such failure has often been
the result of ignorance of the requirements or of insurmountable
obstacles in the student's preparatory school curriculum. Again,
many students have been forced to
take up languages in these schools
in which they had no interest and
which were not as well adapted to
their future vocations as would have
been work in other languages.
The recognition of Spanish also
will aid those who wish to take up
this language in preparatory school,
but, because of the entrance regulations to be obtained, have been
unable to follow their inclinations.
Entrance examinations have
hitherto been held in both September and June. The setting of the
former month as the official time
of these examinations, however,
does not exclude the taking of the
June examinations. Those who
prefer to take the latter are still
able to do so, only, instead of the
Hopkins examinations, they will
take the examinations of the College Entrance Examination Board.
These examinations will be given in
the Academic Building of the University at Homewood from June 19
to 24, 1916, inclusive. For these
examinations, the Board charges a
fee of five dollars, payable before
June 5, 1916.

Plans for the taking of the Senior
Class pictures for the Hullabaloo
have been announced and the class
banquet committee has been appointed. •
The arrangements for the taking
of the class pictures are the most
novel ever undertaken by any graduating class. The plans were announced at the class meeting last
Tuesday, and all were instructed
to subm:t the time which will be
most convenient for their sittings.
The pictures will be taken on the
top floor of the physics laboratory.
For this purpose the entire upper
floor of the building has been temporarily converted into a studio,
which will be occupied by White,
the New York photographer. Mr.
White has a national reputation for
the theatrical portraits he has made
for the best of the current magazines, and his work is considered
among authorities as among the best
in the country.
The taking of the pictures will
begin this Tuesday. Each member
of the Class of 1916 will be photographed at the time which is most
convenient to him, and six photographs will be taken of each man,
from which he may take his pick.
The price of each picture appearing in the Hullabaloo will be two
dollars and fifty cents, and there
will be a reduction of one dollar to
all seniors who have more than four
dollars' worth of pictures finished.
The senior banquet committee is
as follows: Samuel Leithiser,
chairman; Luke Vickers, Franklin
Ludington, Clarence McDowell and
Edmund Spieker. The banquet is
expected to take place sometime
next month, and the committee expresses itself as confident that, from
point of view of both material and
conviviality, it will be one of the
best ever given by a senior class.
After the appointment of the banquet committee, President Tingley
announced that the senior "party"
would take place at the end of the
year. He also read to the class
extracts from a,letter of the "Hullabaloo" engraver, in which the art
productions which had been sent in
were very highly praised.

Those entered for the tournament

At the nineteenth annual interclass debate and public speaking
contest, held last Friday evening
in McCoy Hall, the seniors defeated
the juniors in a hotly contested
struggle, and the Adams medal was
won by Morton K. Rothschild.
The public speaking contest,
which occupied the first place on
the program, was one of the most
interesting which has been heard in
McCoy Hall in recent years. The
three speakers were all of high calibre, and the selections which they
gave were such as to hold the audiench from the first word to the last.
Robert R. Duncan, the first speaker, gave Senator Thurston's speech
on "Intervention in Cuba." He
spoke in a clear, well-modulated
voice, and the interpretation which
he gave to Thurston's stirring appeal was excellent. Reuben Oppenheimer, the next speaker, gave Senator Hoar's speech on "America and
the Philippines." He also interpreted his speech well, using his
voice to the best advantage. Morton K. Rothschild, the last speaker,
gave President Wilson's speech on
"The Significance of the Civil War."
His voice was extremely good, and
his graceful, clean-cut gestures
served to bring out his quiet eloquence to its full advantage.
The subject of the debate was
"Resolved, that for State legislatures a unicameral is preferable to
a bicameral system." The juniors
upheld the affirmative of this ques*tion, the seniors the negative.
The junior team was composed
of Alexander A. Weech, Randolph
Smith and Alexander A. Steinbach,
chairman; Lawrence H. Baker was
alternate and Frederick P. Hall, adviser. The senior team consisted
of Harrison C. Coffin, George F.
Ludington and Thomas J. Tingley,
chairman; with Manuel G. Gichner,
alternate, and Clarence W. McDowell, adviser.
Weech, opening the debate, attacked the bicameral system of legislature and outlined the plan which
the affirmative was proposing. He
spoke quietly and deliberately and
seemed thoroughly at home upon
the platform. Coffin, the first speaker for the negative, plunged into his
subject almost immediately, hurling
shaft after shaft of stinging sarcasm at his opponents, and brilliantly defending the system which they
had attacked. Smith, the second
speaker for the affirmative, continued along the lines which Weech
had outlined. His arguments were

SWIMMERS PROMISING WELL
Many Out for Positions on Independent
Swimming Team—Most of Stars Back.
New Men Showing Up Well.

The independent swimming team
of the University is rapidly rounding into shape, and prospects for
the 1916 season look very prosperous indeed. With the exception of
George Penniman, the team consists
of the same members as last year's
squad, with the addition of McCormick, Kirk, Marshall, Black and
Kefover of the Freshman Class.
H. A. Rowland, last year's captain, who, it was feared at first,
would not be able to swim this year
on account of parental objections,
is back again. Rowland is an especially valuable man to have on the
team, for besides his specialties (the
50 and mo yards), in which he has
won many South Atlantic medals,
he can swim the 220 and the breast
stroke events.
With Captain Hoffman, Woodward and Rowland as a nucleus
around which to build,, the outlook
of the team is very bright indeed.
Fulton, also of last year's team,
has been absent from practice on account of sickness, but is expected to
return this week.
The schedule for this year comprises two trips, besides many encounters at home. Swarthmore,
which was beaten by our team so
badly last year, will again be visited.
The University of Pennsylvania will
be met this year instead of Princeton.
The practices are held three afternoons a week in the Young Men's
Christian Association tank.
Kefover, a freshman from St.
James' School, is showing up well
as a plunger and should give Nicholson a good rub for the position.
Besides Hoffman, the diving department also has Evans, Kirk and
Thurman. The short distances are
to be taken care of by Rowland,
Fulton, Woodward, Nicholson and
arshall, and the longer races will
be pres:ded over by Black, McCormick, Rowland and Primrose. Several other members of the squad are
giving some of these men a hard
task in holding down their positions, and keen competition is shown
among the candidates.
The polo team will presumably be
better this year than last, by reason
of the enlargement of the squad.
Brinton and Johnson, the shining
lights of last year's polo team, are
again back at practice, and with
Hoffman, the two Woodwards, Gorman and Primrose on the squad,
Hopkins should make a name for
herself at water polo.

THE NEWS-LETTER wishes to of-

I•

fer the Class of 1917 its hearty congratulations on the step which it
has taken in regard to military
training at Hopkins. It does so,
not because a course of military
training was favored, but because
the Class of 1917 possessed enough
initiative to put itself on record in
regard to one of the most weighty
questions which is agitating not only
this University, but every college
and university in the United States.
The question of national defense
has swept over this country like a
whirlwind. Twelve months ago,
Hopkins would have regarded a
proposal to institute a course of
military training within its conservative walls only as a question
for a somewhat far-fetched collegiate debate. Now that proposal has
been endorsed by one-fourth of the
undergraduate student body.
This question concerns the students, and, before any decision is
reached which would commit the
Hopkins of the future to a set
course of action, student opinion
should go on record as to what that
decision should be. The Junior
Class has made the first step; the
three other classes should follow,
and follow immediately.

Wanted—Participants.

The interclass debate of last Friday evening gave to the attendant
public, and, incidentally, to a fair
proportion of Hopkins' students, an
insight into a phase of Hopkins'
activities which only comes into the
public sight at rather long intervals,
and which consequently does not
'attract the constant attention which
is accorded to athletic activities.
That this activity, when, for a brief
time, it does hold the stage, is amply capable of occupying it in an interesting manner, was proved by the
large crowd which witnessed the
contest last Friday, and that it represents Hopkins to good advantage
was shown by the speeches of the
debaters themselves.
Within two or three weeks, tryouts will be held for places on the
'Varsity teams which are sent out
to meet the teams of North Carolina and Virginia. For three successive years, Hopkins has been
the winner of this triangular debate, and its success has attracted
attention in the debating circles of
colleges throughout the country.
In the past, the idea seems to
have prevailed that these teams were
chosen almost entirely from the
men who took part in the seniorjunior debates: While the majority
of 'Varsity debaters undoubtedly
have been chosen from this material, the idea in itself is erroneous.

LACROSSE SQUAD SHOWS UP WELL
More Freshmen Should Come Out at
Once, Says Coach Wolfe—Progress
of the Team Excellent.

The recent work of the lacrosse
squad has been very encouraging.
Head Coach Wolfe was delighted
with the spirit and enthusiasm displayed in a practice game held
following the freshman-sophomore
track meet. The team is not as
far advanced as it should be at this
time of the year, but if the men
keep up their excellent work this
handicap will soon be overcome.
Coach Wolfe gave a "chalk" talk
last Saturday.
At present, the coach expects to
begin outdoor practice at Homewood in less than two months, and
the meantime will be spent in perfecting the men in stick-work. Four
days a week are spent on this feature of the game. Wednesday and
Saturday are devoted to team work
and scrimmages.
Although the last appeal for more
men was answered in some measure, there is a great need for more
freshmen, and if the members of
the freshmen class do not immediately respond to that call the hope
for the future of the team will be
darkened. New men are not only
needed for future championships
but also for the present. Mr. Paul
W. Sutton, the captain of the team,
will gladly see any man who is interested in lacrosse, and will give
him any desired information.
Since Carlisle has dropped athletics entirely, the lacrosse team has
been forced to cancel its dates with
that college, and the schedule has
had to be readjusted. Consequently, it is not yet possible to announce
the coming program, but the coaches promise one of the strongest
schedules ever followed.

AMERICAN ACADEMY OFFERS
TWO FELLOWSHIPS IN CLASSICS

The school of classical studies of
the American Academy in Rome announces its annual competitions for
fellowships in classical studies. Two
fellowships—one of $1,000 a year
for one year and one of like amount
to last two years—will be awarded
to the winners of a competition open
to all unmarried citizens of the
United States who comply with a
set of. regulations drawn up by the
academy.
Sections i and 2 of the regulations follow:
"Section 1. All persons desiring
to compete for a fellowship must
fill in a form of application, Which
will be furnished by the secretary
of the academy upon request, and
file the same with the secretary not
later than March 1, together with
such letters of reference and other
documents or evidence as they may
desire to submit. Application and
papers must be submitted in triplicate.

"Sec. 2. They must submit evidence of attainment in Latin literature, Greek literature, Greek and
Roman history and archwology, also
an ability to use German and
French. They will be required to
present published or unpublished
papers, so as to indicate their fitness to undertake special work in
Rome."
The fellows will be selected without examination, other than the submission of the required papers, by
the fellowship jury, of which Dr.
James C. Egbert, Columbia University, is chairman.

STUDENTS INVITED TO CAMPS
General Wood U ges All to Attend the
Camps at Plattsburg and Chattanooga,and Tells of Benefits.

The Maryland League for NaDefense has forwarded the following communication from General
Wood to the president of the senior
class:
HEADQUARTERS EASTERN DEPT.
GOVERNORS ISLAND, NEW
YORK CITY.
January 17, 1916.
Dear Sir—You will find herewith a bulletin containing full information in regard to a military
training camp to be held in your
section of the country with the hope
that you will be interested in this
subject.
You will note, first, that applicants are desired principally from
those who have had college, university,-high school (or corresponding school) education. Non-graduates are not excluded, but each case
will be decided on its merits with a
view to maintaining a level in the
progressive scheme of development.
The training given at these camps is
very intensive, covering in a period
of four weeks as much as possible
of the fundamental education of an
officer. This calls for a well-trained
mind. In the second place, past experience has shown that this class
of young men is the first to join the
colors in time of war, and many of
them regardless of their skill in
military matters receive commissions. This has been the procedure
in times past. It is right and necessary that these young men should be
fully informed,as to the tremendous
responsibility which will come to
them with the command of men and
the irreparable loss which may be
caused by unskilled leadership.
Furthermore, as citizens of military age and as members of the unorganized militia under the constitution, it is necessary for the intelligent discharge of their military obligations that they should be as well
informed as possible on these matters. The President has said in a
recent message * * * "it will
be right enough, right American
policy, based upon our accustomed
principles and practices, to provide
a system by which every citizen who
will volunteer for the training may
be made familiar with ,the use of
modern arms, the rudiments of drill
and maneuver, and the maintenance
and sanitation of camps. We should
encourage such training and make
it a means of discipline which our
young men will learn to value."
* * *
At these camps great stress is laid
upon personal hygiene and camp sanitation and a serious effort is made to
teach men how to take care of themselves in camp and at maneuvers, as
well as to familiarize them with the
use of arms. The conduct of the
camps tends to establish habits of
promptness and exactness, and to
the careful observance and prompt
execution of instructions. A serious

effort is made through lectures to
convey a sound and correct idea of
the military policy of the United
States as exemplified, by our past
wars and particular attention is
given to the general subject of military history.
Secondary to these more serious
purposes of the camp, there is to
be considered the physical benefit
of a healthy, out-of-doors life,
vigorous exercise, discipline, good
food and association With a fine lot
of men from every section of the
country with whom, as past experience shows, a very intimate bond
is formed based on hard work in
camp and maneuvers and the consciousness of serving a good cause.
For these reasons national statesmen and legislators, famous lawyers, great bankers and merchants,
and many high state and city officials have stood elbow to elbow in
the ranks, at such camps, with men
who labor for a daily wage, and
both are prowl of it.
The whole effect of the camps
has been excellent both from the
standpoint of increasing the sense
of each man's responsibility to the
nation for service and his obligation
to fit himself to render it effectively
and efficiently.
Attendance at the camp will not
increase either the legal or moral
obligation of those who attend.
The intention is merely to equip
those taking the course of training
to fulfill with more efficiency and
usefulness obligations which are already laid upon them as citizens of
the United States.
Very sincerely yours,
.LEONARD WOOD,
Major General U. S. Army.
The following is the schedule of
the camps which will be organized
this summer:
Northern Section, (Plattsburg,
N. Y.)—First camp, Senior Division, June 5 to July 22; Second
camp, Junior Division, July 5 to
August 8; Third camp, Senior Division, July 12 to August 8; Fourth
camp, Senior Division, August 10
to September 6.
Southern Section, (Fort Oglethorpe, Ga., Chattanooga)—First
camp, Senior Division, April 3 to
April 3o ; Second camp, Senior Division, May 3 to May 3o; Third
camp, Senior Division, June 3 to
June 3o; Fourth camp, Junior Division, July 5 to August 8.
The Junior Division comprises
undergraduates in colleges, universities, and those students in public
and private schools who have
reached a grade equivalent to senior
class, high school.
The Senior Division comprises
graduates of colleges and universities, and other citizens between the
ages of 21 and 45, who have received an equivalent education.
Further information in regard to
these camps may be obtained by
application to "The Officer in
Charge," Military Training Schools,
Governors Island, N. Y. Indication should be made of the section
preferred.

Sir—I am writing to you in order
to express by appreciation of the
enthusiasm which is being shown
over the class basket-ball contests.

my opinion valuable assets to a college curriculum, and all of the

between the classes.

the present basket-ball games in the

WOODPECKERS CAN GET DRUNK,
IS VERDICT OF DR. WATSON

Prof. J. 11. Watson, of the Phychology Department of this University, is of the opinion that it is
possible for woodpeckers to get
drunk.
Professor Watson has committed
himself to this statement in answering the inquiry of Prof. Burges
Johnson, and his opinion is quoted
in an article in Harper's Magazine, where the question of the
sobriety of woodpeckers is discussed
by some of the most eminent naturalists in the country.
Professor Johnson became interested in this problem as the result
of certain observations ill a camp
in Maine. The authorities to whom
he wrote concerning this question
disagree widely.
Ernest Thompson Seton says:
"The story of woodpeckers getting
drunk on fermented sap is an absurd fable." John Burroughs answers: "Both. birds and insect's
might get drunk on the fermented
sap." Ernest H. Baynes says: "I
do not think it impossible, perhaps
not improbable."
Professor Watson's answer is:
"I have seen robins in a `loggy' condition upon very ripe berries in the
South."

Beside the regular events, there
were three events closed to Hopkins men, in which novices and
"black-listed" men could compete.
Reese came through first in both
the 30-yard and 220-yard dashes,
with Weech a close second in
both. The 44o-yard dash was a
nip-and-tuck fight the entire distance between Gerry Hall and
Weech.- Alternating in the lead all
the way, the two men finished so
close together that it was difficult
for the spectators to be sure that
Hall would get the decision.
As regards individual point-winners, Tommy McDonagh was high
man for the Baltimore Athletic Association, with eleven points; while
Sutton took ten for Hopkins, besides running on the winning relay.
Uhler and Dempster each made six.
The meet was run off in very
snappy order and is looked upon as
a success in every way. The summary is as follows:
